Award.AwardTitle: RII Track-4: Operando Analysis of Fuel Cell Materials at Advanced Light Source
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description
The 21st century will likely face many challenges, among them being the increasing societal need for non-stationary energy production. Hydrogen fuel cells are one of the most promising technologies for addressing and mastering this task. This project takes on the challenge to advance the knowledge of processes and mechanisms occurring during operation of fuel cells at the atomic and molecular levels. The structure of materials of fuel cells at the nanometer scale of electronic structures will be probed using the instrumentation available at the Advanced Light Source facility, part of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. The ability to characterize solid-liquid interfaces in fuel cells at the atomic and molecular levels under realistic operational conditions is the key to tackling some of the most fundamental and profound problems in nature as well as electrochemistry. This opportunity is extending the capacity of scientists and students from the University of New Mexico (UNM) to conduct scientific research in this area. It will allow research faculty and students from UNM to realize New Mexico's potential for sustainable energy development through building a collaboration with state-of-the-science facilities not available at this time within the state of NM. This fellowship will not only support training of the research faculty at the forefront of analytical chemistry but also training of graduate students, thereby creating an opportunity for graduate students to conduct research at the interface between basic and applied science.

Technical Description
The best performing hydrogen-based fuel cells rely on platinum-derived electrocatalysts. The most promising class of alternative platinum-group-metal-free materials is based on graphene-like carbon containing nitrogen and transition metal (Metal, Nitrogen, Carbon material; MNC). Understanding the specific roles of nitrogen and metal in fuel cell properties, such as activity, stability, and durability, is a prerequisite for the rational design of fuel cell electrocatalysts with improved performance. The goal of the project is the investigation of structures of electrodes using operando spectroscopic techniques and determining specific roles of chemical structures in the reaction within complete fuel cell operating under applied potential in the presence of oxidants for cathodic and reductants for anodic reactions. The chemical structure of electrode materials, reactants, and products will be studied under applied potential using ambient-pressure X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) utilizing the synchrotron light source in a realistic fuel cell experiment. Of fundamental interest to this project is understanding the mechanism of fuel cell reactions at the molecular level. The conversion between electrical and chemical energy occurs in the interface region between a solid electrode material, liquid electrolyte, and gaseous phase. Developing methods for probing the tri-phase interphase under different applied potentials in operando will be pursued. probing the tri-phase interphase under different applied potentials in operando will be pursued. Comprehensive understanding based on a study of full electrode systems under operando conditions will result in the identification of the role that each type of chemistry present in an MNC electrode has in the reaction. This will, in turn, accelerate rational catalyst design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 21st century faces many challenges among them are the increasing societal need for non-stationary energy production. Hydrogen fuel cells are one of the most promising technologies for addressing and mastering this task. The project took a challenge to advance the knowledge of processes and mechanisms occurring during the operation of fuel cells at atomic and molecular levels.

Chemical analysis of surfaces of constituents of fuel cells at the nanometer level can be accomplished using laboratory-based surface analytical equipment which analyzes these materials in ultra-high vacuum. In situ and operando characterization of components of fuel cells in realistic operational conditions are the key to tackling some of the most fundamental and profound problems in nature as well as electrochemistry.

This project provided an opportunity for unique access to perform in situ experiments in near ambient conditions relevant to fuel cell operation using high energy synchrotron light available at Advanced Light Source (ALS) of Lawrence Berkley National Laboratory.

Research centers with synchrotron light sources are at the forefront of developing operando analytical methods. Through this fellowship I utilized synchrotron light capabilities to a much greater extent than I was engaged previously through beamline time applications, creating new and exciting skills and knowledge. It was a rare opportunity for a scientist from academia to be at the forefront of research that is driven by unique capabilities available only at such facilities as ALS. 

In this project we have synthesized building blocks of materials based on graphene-like carbon containing nitrogen and transition metal (MNC) and studied oxygen reduction reaction on the surface of those materials using ambient pressure X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (APXPS) instrument at ALS. The relationship between individual synthesis steps, chemistry and morphology of synthesized building blocks and resulting activity created an important input into optimizing synthetic routes. Optimization of synthesis based on structure-to-property relationships derived facilitated the creation of more active and durable catalysts. Adsorption of oxygen on individual building blocks and optimized catalysts studied by APXPS provided a missing link between a multitude of chemical structures existing in this family of materials and mechanism of reaction. The results of the in situ APXPS and electrochemical testing identified chemical structures that are responsible for two parallel mechanisms of oxygen reduction, via more efficient direct reduction of oxygen to water, which occurs on iron coordinated to nitrogen Fe-Nx sites, and via less efficient two-step mechanism, where protonated and hydrogenated nitrogen catalyzes the reduction of oxygen to hydrogen peroxide, hence decreasing the selectivity and efficiency of oxygen reduction. Invaluable information on parasitic reactions that are catalyzed by undesirable chemical moieties provided input for rational engineering of more selective and active materials.

The interface of engineering and basic sciences this fellowship encompasses opened opportunities for graduate students to be successful in the workplace that is increasingly characterized by interdisciplinary research. This fellowship created an opportunity for graduate students to conduct research at the interface between basic and applied science and to get access to unique capabilities. This unique opportunity promoted research faculty and students from UNM to realize New Mexico's potential for sustainable energy development through building a collaboration with state-of-the-art facilities with unique equipment not available at this moment within the State of New Mexico.
